headline: The most interesting Republican primaries of 2022
sentences: He had Trump's endorsement  until Trump revoked it, complaining that Brooks wanted to focus too much on future elections rather than look back on 2020 (which is often the code GOP politicians use when they don't agree with Trump's false claims).

(Trump recently bragged to The Post that one of the six, Tom Rice, is getting crushed in South Carolina.?) His top target is Cheney in Wyoming, who has been kicked out of House GOP leadership for her role in the Jan. 6 investigation.

Vance, even though, according to Washington Post reporting, some of Trump's own advisers wanted him to choose former state GOP chair Jane Timken or former Ohio treasurer Josh Mandel, whom they view as more electable statewide.

In many of these contests, former president Donald Trump has put his reputation at stake by endorsing unconventional candidates and pursuing vendettas against members of his party who bucked him while he was president.

Pennsylvania: Pennsylvania, as a swing state, could determine which party controls the Senate next year  and Trump made another endorsement unpopular with his party when he backed TV doctor Mehmet Oz for its open seat.
(In another red state's race for governor, Trump is campaigning for a controversial candidate: Charles Herbster, who is running in Nebraska and has been accused of sexual assault.)
Trump also endorsed Kelly Tshibaka to challenge Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R), who voted to convict Trump after the House impeached him for his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot.
After Cawthorn alleged that D.C. leaders used cocaine and invited him to an orgy, top Republicans started actively supporting one of his challengers, state Sen. Chuck Edwards.
Alabama: There are few Republican politicians who championed Trump's false 2020 fraud claims as much as Rep. Mo Brooks of Alabama, who is running for an open Senate seat.
The only clue we have is that McGeachin has tried to remove coronavirus restrictions when Little goes out of state, only to have Little reverse them when he returns.
For secretary of state, Trump is backing a congressman willing to elevate his false fraud claims, Rep. Jody Hice  unlike the incumbent, Brad Raffensperger.
Georgia governor and secretary of state: In Georgia, Trump is focused on proving that the Republican Party supports his false claims of election fraud.
Brian Kemp (R) refused to help Trump overturn his 2020 loss in the state, so Trump endorsed Kemp's challenger, former Republican senator David Perdue.
Oz's candidacy was originally treated as a joke by establishment Republicans, and opponents could mine his years of controversial medical statements.
For months, the former president stayed out of the primary and watched as the candidates tried to out-Trump each other with controversial statements.
North Carolina: Trump picked the underdog in North Carolina's open Senate race  a seat Republicans probably need to hold to take back the majority.
It is all about winning!? Trump said in a statement in which he acknowledged Vance's anti-Trump past and asserting that the candidate gets it now.
Alaska: Alaska has an open primary  meaning candidates compete against each other regardless of party  but the Republicans are the ones to watch.
(Vance went so far to the right that he won the backing of Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican provocateur who represents Georgia.)
Murkowski is still competitive in part because of Alaska's new ranked-choice voting system, which rewards less-partisan candidates.
Liz Cheney and the impeachment Republicans: Ten House Republicans voted to impeach Trump for his role in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
Skipping over a much more traditional candidate, former hedge fund manager David McCormick, to endorse Oz is another risky move.
She is one of the best-known politicians in the country and has Trump's endorsement  but it's not a given that she'll win.
Now Brooks is trying to win without Trump, against well-funded (yet less Trumpian) opponents Katie Britt and Mike Durant.
Four have retired, but six are running for reelection, and Trump is propping up primary challengers against all of them.

Even in safe races Republicans expect to win this November, the real drama is playing out in the primaries.
(Perdue lost his seat in the 2021 runoff  a loss GOP Senate leaders blame on Trump and his fraud claims.)

Unseating a governor is one of the hardest things to do in politics, but Trump is going to try.
(The Senate is split 50-50, and Democrats hold the majority in the House by just a few seats.)
